docs.snippet: Designing In the Streets      The clock is ticking. March 27 is the Public Art Fund's latest deadline for emerging New York State artists to submit proposals to create a work in a public place.    The Public Art Fund, a nonprofit group that organi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Designing In the Streets The clock is ticking. March 27 is the Public Art Fund's latest deadline for emerging New York State artists to submit proposals to create a work in a public place. The Public Art Fund, a nonprofit group that organizes art projects around New York City, has made such requests twice before. Its three-year-old project, ''In the Public Realm,'' is geared specifically to giving new names a chance to create public art.
docs.abstract: Inside Art column; Public Art Fund invites emerging New York artists to submit proposals for works in public places; will also select sculptor for award from Greenwall Foundation; J Paul Getty Museum, with additional space in new home, will exhibit works of 17th-century Dutch sculptor Adriaen de Vries; photo; show is collaboration with Rijksmuseum and National Museum in Stockholm; National Gallery in Washington announces acquisitions including Holbein drawing; Brenda Richardson, longtime curator at Baltimore Museum, leaves after administrative restructuring by new director, Doreen Bolger (S)

docs.snippet: Back in the 1960's, Bob Dylan sang, ''My name it is nothing.'' But at the 40th annual Grammy Awards ceremony, the Dylan name was a guaranteed winner. Mr. Dylan's album ''Time Out of Mind'' brought him three Grammys, including album of the year. Th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Back in the 1960's, Bob Dylan sang, ''My name it is nothing.'' But at the 40th annual Grammy Awards ceremony, the Dylan name was a guaranteed winner. Mr. Dylan's album ''Time Out of Mind'' brought him three Grammys, including album of the year. The rock category was dominated by Jakob Dylan and his own band, the Wallflowers, who won awards for best rock performance by a duo or group and best rock song for their hit ''One Headlight.'' ''Time Out of Mind'' has been widely hailed as Bob Dylan's best album in two decades. Mr. Dylan's pioneering albums in the 1960's were not recognized by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which chooses the Grammy Awards. He has shared some awards and won in 1980 for best male rock vocalist and in 1995 for traditional folk album with ''World Gone Wrong.'' In 1991, the recording academy gave him a Lifetime Achievement prize, a noncompetitive award.
docs.abstract: National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences holds 40th annual Grammy Awards ceremony at Radio City Music Hall in New York City; Bob Dylan (Album), Paula Cole (New Artist), Shawn Colvin (Single Record) and Jakob Dylan (Rock Performance) are among winners; photo (M)

headline.main: Dylans, Father and Son, Gather Grammys; Shawn Colvin Wins for 'Sunny'

docs.snippet: EVENTS  Other Times, Other Places    While many movie fans are looking ahead to the Academy Awards, Symphony Space is looking back to foreign films that were Oscar winners and nominees. A series of screenings, ''The Envelope Please: 50 Years of Fo...
docs.lead_paragraph: EVENTS Other Times, Other Places While many movie fans are looking ahead to the Academy Awards, Symphony Space is looking back to foreign films that were Oscar winners and nominees. A series of screenings, ''The Envelope Please: 50 Years of Foreign Film and the Academy Awards,'' begins tomorrow night with Vittorio De Sica's ''Bicycle Thief'' (Italy, 1949) at 7 P.M. and Emir Kusturica's ''When Father Was Away on Business'' (Yugoslavia, 1985) at 8:45. The double features continue on Tuesdays through May 19 at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street. Box office: (212) 864-5400.
docs.abstract: Symphony Space to screen series of foreign films that won or were nominated for Academy Awards over past 50 years; dozen sculptures by Bernini are among 35 works in exhibition of Italian baroque terra cottas from Hermitage at Art Institute of Chicago; New Zealand is set to hold Arts Festival; Toni Morrison will discuss her writing career with Anna Deavere Smith at 92d St Y; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gillian Blake, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Blake of Orange, Conn., was married yesterday to Oscar Kelley Anderson 3d, the son of Alexandra Anderson-Spivy and Mr. Anderson Jr., both of New York. The Rev. Susannah R. Smith performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The couple graduated from Harvard University, the bride magna cum laude.

docs.snippet: THE shocking notion that, some day, it might be possible to clone human beings seems to propel ethicists, press pundits and the like into flights of science fantasy. All offer their most provocative scenarios. And so, inevitably, do a few brave sc...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE shocking notion that, some day, it might be possible to clone human beings seems to propel ethicists, press pundits and the like into flights of science fantasy. All offer their most provocative scenarios. And so, inevitably, do a few brave scientists. For the ethicist Dr. Arthur Caplan of the University of Pennsylvania, the possibilities include the Dorian Gray scenario, named after Oscar Wilde's story, ''The Picture of Dorian Gray,'' whose eponymous hero stays young while the picture of him ages. A child who is a clone would have to look at a parent who is his or her aging identical twin.
docs.abstract: Gina Kolata article on view of Dr Davor Solter of Max-Planck Institute of Immunobiology in Freiburg, Germany, that women could become all powerful in future society that needs their eggs for human cloning; photo (M)

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; In the Game of Cloning, Women Hold All the Cards

docs.snippet: IF YOU TAKE away the art and keep the commerce, who's No. 1 in Hollywood right now? Shortly before the Oscar nominations were announced recently, the results of another annual popularity contest, one that has lasted almost as long as the Academy A...
docs.lead_paragraph: IF YOU TAKE away the art and keep the commerce, who's No. 1 in Hollywood right now? Shortly before the Oscar nominations were announced recently, the results of another annual popularity contest, one that has lasted almost as long as the Academy Awards, were revealed. Quigley Publishing Company, which has produced the International Motion Picture Almanac for 64 years, released the results of its annual Top 10 Moneymaking Stars poll. Among this poll's top 10 stars of 1997, only two, Jack Nicholson (for ''As Good as It Gets'') and Robin Williams (for ''Good Will Hunting''), also received Oscar nominations. The poll, conducted since 1932, asks several hundred motion-picture theater owners in the United States and Canada to name the actors responsible for bringing in the most dollars at the box office in the previous year. This time around, as usual, it provides a fascinating glimpse into how the exhibiting arm of the movie industry views stars. That view is purely commercial; it has nothing to do with foolishness like artistic prestige. The list also tends to be much more volatile and dependent on the impact of individual hit movies than other Hollywood power polls, which generally take a longer view of star clout and bankability.
docs.abstract: Harrison Ford tops the list of Hollywood's top moneymaking stars for 1997, as compiled by Quigley Publishing Co; following him in order are Julia Roberts, Leonardo DiCaprio, Will Smith, Tom Cruise, Jack Nicholson, Jim Carrey, John Travolta, Robin Williams and Tommy Lee Jones; photos (M)

headline.main: At the Top By Way of a Bottom Line

docs.snippet: Fiona Apple at the Supper Club  TUESDAY -- Fiona Apple will perform at a reception and awards ceremony at the Supper Club, 240 West 47th Street, honoring the Beastie Boys and Salt-n-Pepa. The evening will raise money for Rock the Vote, a group org...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fiona Apple at the Supper Club TUESDAY -- Fiona Apple will perform at a reception and awards ceremony at the Supper Club, 240 West 47th Street, honoring the Beastie Boys and Salt-n-Pepa. The evening will raise money for Rock the Vote, a group organized by the recording industry that encourages young people to register and vote. The evening will begin with drinks at 8. Tickets, $150, from (212) 245-6570.

docs.snippet: Journeying from page to screen, books enrich the films on television this week.      THE FUGITIVE (1947) is John Ford's strong, brooding version of Graham Greene's ''Power and the Glory.'' It's a harsh story of a poor, dedicated rebel priest, hunt...
docs.lead_paragraph: Journeying from page to screen, books enrich the films on television this week. THE FUGITIVE (1947) is John Ford's strong, brooding version of Graham Greene's ''Power and the Glory.'' It's a harsh story of a poor, dedicated rebel priest, hunted down in a totalitarian country. Henry Fonda makes a memorable protagonist and religious martyr. As his chief pursuer and tormentor, Pedro Armendariz proves aptly effective, as does Dolores Del Rio, in the role of a woman from the priest's past -- Tuesday at 4:45 P.M. on AMC.

docs.snippet: War and Peace: An Epic of Bugs      The director John Lasseter is well known as a master of computer animation and screenwriting. But recently, Mr. Lasseter, the director of ''Toy Story'' and the coming animated feature ''A Bug's Life,'' spoke exc...
docs.lead_paragraph: War and Peace: An Epic of Bugs The director John Lasseter is well known as a master of computer animation and screenwriting. But recently, Mr. Lasseter, the director of ''Toy Story'' and the coming animated feature ''A Bug's Life,'' spoke excitedly about a new passion: clover. ''You know, you just think of the ground as grass and stuff, but when you really get down in it and look up, it's amazing how translucent that world is,'' Mr. Lasseter (above) said. ''It's like stained-glass windows in some of our scenes. We have the bugs enter a forest of clovers and it's amazing. It's so beautiful. They're like sequoias. That's what we can do now with the technology.''
docs.abstract: At the Movies column; director John Lasseter, known for computer animation and screenwriting, describes new animated feature, A Bug's Life; John Sayles comments on lifetime achievement award for screenwriting from Writers Guild, as well as new film; Men With Guns is metaphorical exploration of violence and intolerance that cost only $2.5 million, and was shot mostly in Mexico using unknown actors speaking in Spanish and Indian languages; 32-year-old filmmaker Bryan Singer discusses his second low-budget movie, Apt Pupil, based on Stephen King novella; photos (S)
